msgSnippet: I agree that the assertTrue is redundant, but it tells the reader (reviewer) that I know what I m doing without my writing a comment. My fingers already know
messageBody:
I agree that the 'assertTrue' is redundant, but it tells the reader
(reviewer) that I know what I'm doing without my writing a comment.
My fingers already know how to type that pattern below.

Dumb question: what's assertThrows?


Thanks
--DP

-----Original Message-----
From: Ilja Preuss [mailto:preuss@...]
Sent: Thursday, July 15, 2004 9:22 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Documenting test cases


David Plass wrote:
> Negative tests are different... I'd write
> public void testExceptions() { // note no throws try {
> method.throwsNPE();
> fail("Should have thrown NPE");
> } catch (NullPointerException expected) {
> assertTrue("Should catch NPE", true);
> }
> }
>
> to test the fact that 'method.throwsNPE' should throw NPE.

Yep, though the assertTrue is kind of redundant, and I prefer the
assertThrows pattern.

And if the method is allowed to throw a new kind of exception, I might
write a such test to document the fact, but I wouldn't want to need to
adapt all the other tests, too...

Cheers, Ilja
